entry.title: SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence 2025
entry.content:
Good news! The learning journey Discovering Business Intelligence using SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence has been updated and now it includes the latest features of 2025.

The three courses will help you master the BI Launch Pad and Web Intelligence tools. 

The first course, titled Discovering SAP BusinessObjects BI Launch Pad, is suitable for business users, analysts, and consultants who want to begin with SAP BusinessObjects.

The course will enable you to:

  • Use Web Intelligence tools to display, interact with, and filter data. 
  • Configure your settings for an improved user experience. 
  • Schedule your documents efficiently and export them. 
  • Share an interactive Web Intelligence document with someone who does not have access to SAP BusinessObjects using the WIDX format. 

The next course, titled Exploring the Fundamental Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, is ideal for users who have completed the BI Launch Pad course and want to create their own documents.

The course will enable you to:

  • Retrieve only the relevant data for your analysis by applying filters at the query level. 
  • Design and format documents that effectively communicate complex analysis to decision-makers. 
  • Write basic formulas and variables‚ÄØto customize your analysis. 
  • Transform your static documents into interactive dashboards using the new interactive report filters. 

The third and final course, titled Exploring the Advanced Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, is designed for users who have completed Exploring the Fundamental Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence and are ready to tackle more complex reporting challenges.

The course will enable you to:

  • Build queries based on a universe, a Microsoft Excel workbook, and a Web Intelligence document. 
  • Visualize and prepare data, then build cubes in Data mode. 
  • Define and apply input and output contexts to control calculation results. 
  • Write complex formulas and variables‚ÄØto customize your analysis. 

In this learning journey, you'll explore each course through easy-to-understand explanations, helpful visuals, and short videos.

If you want to practice, you have two scenarios to choose from:

  • Hands-on exercises with guided simulations, which are free.
  • Hands-on exercises with an exercise handbook and access to an SAP practice system. You need a subscription to the SAP Learning Hub portal.

Pass all the quizzes and receive a digital badge that will allow you to share your recently acquired knowledge across your social and professional networks.

Start your journey today and unlock the full potential of your business data with SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence!

entry.title: 02 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Clean Core Guidelines
entry.content:
The purpose of this blog is to share Clean Core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, based on my experience. This is not official SAP documentation or recommendation.

Clean Core is a key topic in SAP S/4HANA Transformation projects and must be adopted as part of the S/4HANA Journey. SAP has delivered tools, frameworks, and Strategy documents to support it, but I haven't seen much content for SAP SuccessFactors HCM projects. I hope this blog addresses this to some extent.

Why is a clean core essential in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?

 Clean Core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing an agile, innovative, and efficient SAP SuccessFactors HCM system, reducing technical debt and manual effort, and adopting a framework for building a maintainable system that leverages standard capabilities wherever possible.

If you are using SAP ERP HCM as Core HR, the system has evolved over the years and is usually customized to support your business processes, Integrations, and reporting. There is a valid reason for customization, but it introduced long-term challenges, technical debt, and high maintenance costs, which are well known, and every customer raises concerns about them.

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Clean Core Guiding Principles: 

  1. Business Processes: Standardize processes (fit-to-standard) to increase efficiency and adapt to market shifts.
  2. Data: Maintain high-quality, consistent data and implement robust governance to improve reporting, Integration, and analytics.
  3. Integration: Use standard APIs (OData, Web Services, ISC), Packaged Integrations, Event Driven Architecture (EDA), and direct API-based integrations to avoid complex custom integrations and Data gaps.
  4. Operations and Upgrades: Manage the lifecycle, ensure efficient monitoring, and adopt the new features of the SAP SuccessFactors HCM system.
  5. Extensibility: Built customer-specific, unique requirements using Extension Center Objects and SAP BTP CAP extensibility using the OData APIs to decouple customizations from the core for upgrade stability and build UI experience using Fiori and implement workflow /automation capabilities using SAP Build.

Business Process Clean Core governance framework:

This is a high-level framework that you could enhance based on your project structure and governance model.

Recommendations for Implementing Clean Core Guiding Principles:

 

  1. SAP SuccessFactors HCM Product Capabilities: Understanding the product capabilities is key to implementing or adopting fit-to-standard clean core guidelines. If the implementation resource lacks SME-level experience, the solution will likely be suboptimal and will usually require significant customization. 2
  2. Guiding principles and standards for each work stream: Create guiding principles and leading practices for each work stream (Functional, Data, Integration, and Extensibility), and ensure the project implementation team, including the customer and SI resources, must follow them as part of implementation to produce outstanding results. 
  3. Skills resources from SI: Having skilled resources from SI (Solution Architect, Functional Leads, and Technical Architect) who are familiar with the clean core implementation is key. Ensuring they own the quality of the work is key and should be part of the statement of work. 
  4. Preferred success service: Preferred success customers -leverage SAP's preferred success services like solution launch checks and success checks to review the SF configuration, Design, Integration strategy, and Integration code during the implementation. 
  5. Review Implementation Design Principles (IDPs): Based on my experience, IDPs are key assets for clean core guidelines. They provide structured guidance for addressing challenging customer requirements and frequently asked questions during the design and implementation phases of a project.

https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/implementation-design-principles#sap-successfactors-recruiting-management-and-employee-central-integration 

      6. SuccessFactors Architecture Leading Practice (ALP): ALP is another key asset for clear core guidelines, and it provides a set of recommended configuration decisions and guidance on topics associated with a SuccessFactors implementation, and a recommendation to drive positive outcomes aligned with the intended system design, leveraging proven success from previous deployments, and avoiding pitfalls.

 https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/architecture-leading-practices

 7. Integrations: Integration is a common area where extensive customization is done, which adds technical debt and high maintenance costs. Make sure that the resources who built integrations have.

 Prior experience in building integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

  • Understanding of SAP SuccessFactors APIs leading practices and Integration tools.
  • Strong integration design skills .
  • Understanding of packaged integrations and capabilities.
  • Integration Center and SAP Integration Suite Capabilities, and when to use these tools for custom integrations. 

 8. Leverage standard capabilities to capture quality data: Implementing proper validation business rules and framework to capture data is key . 

9) Data retention and Purge Data: Setting up the proper data retention rules and purging unnecessary data based on your data retention requirements will help you maintain key data. 

10) Monitoring Tools:  Leverage standard capabilities offered by SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and SAP Solutions like Cloud ALM to monitor the jobs and schedules, which reduces system maintenance costs. 

11)Handling Product gaps: Some requirements will challenge the product capabilities, and they will be identified as gaps. Now, how you handle the product gaps is very key, based on my experience below,

  • Check if the functionality can be achieved using Extension Center Objects ( MDF). 
  • If MDF is not a solution, then check the Product roadmap to see if anything is planned in the upcoming releases. 
  • If Options 1 and 2 are not viable, then check if the partner has built any BTP Extension solutions in the App store. 
  • If a partner solution is not available, you can leverage the SAP BTP Extensibility Framework to extend SAP SuccessFactors and build the required functionality.

Commonly Asked Questions: 

 1)Creating custom fields and extension Center Objects is deviating from the clean core?

 No. But it is essential to check whether the functionality can be achieved using standard fields before using custom fields and the extension Center (MDF) object.

 2)How can I check if my SI is implementing and following clear core guidelines? 

Having the right skill resources for the project implementation is key. It is strongly recommended that key SI resources be validated before onboarding.

 3) What are the assets SAP has delivered for SI and Customers?

 I have used the following assets, and they have always helped.

  •  Implementation Design Principles covering all topics.
  • Architecture Leading Practices.
  • Process Maps.
  • Leading practices document.

  4)What are the areas that cause technical debt in SAP SuccessFactors HCM? 

Technical debt refers to the implied cost of future rework, Manual work, and maintenance resulting from choosing quick, short-term implementation or configuration solutions over more robust, long-term best practices. 

  • Integrations with External systems ‚Äì Building custom integrations with Poor Integration Design and coding standards
  • Manual workarounds and manual data maintenance processes
  • Customizations over Standard Functionality, Creating custom fields and MDF objects without governance.
  • Not ready to optimize business processes and build a solution that requires so much effort to maintain.
  • Not automating data imports.

5) Is optimizing business processes a must for a clean core?

 Yes. Optimizing some of the business processes is not possible due to various factors, which is reality, but as a customer having a mindset to optimize is very key, and checking the solution design options from the SI team and walking through with business and HR is always recommended.

entry.title: From Adrenaline to Assurance: How SAP Commerce Cloud Customers Made Peak Season Routine
entry.content:
Black Friday and Cyber Monday have long been the ultimate stress test for digital commerce. For many businesses, these high-traffic events once meant long nights, constant monitoring, and firefighting to keep systems running. For SAP Commerce Cloud customers, last year marked a turning point ‚Äì SAP-led proactive readiness strategies helped businesses stay ahead of risk and keep experiences smooth. This year, those strategies were not only repeated but enhanced by SAP, making peak season feel routine for leading brands even as order volumes surged.

Why SAP‚Äôs Proactive Approach Keeps Getting Better

When every second counts, prevention is better than cure. automation. SAP Commerce Cloud customers who embraced SAP‚Äôs proactive playbook last year doubled down this year with expanded coverage and smarter automation. SAP AI-driven insights continuously monitored capacity, configuration, and operations, so action happened before customers noticed.

Automated checks replaced manual lists, and support teams were ready to step in early ‚Äì quietly resolving issues before they became problems.

The result? A stronger, more unified, signal-led workflow that kept everything running seamlessly across consecutive peak seasons.

What Was Enhanced This Year ‚Äì and Why It Mattered

  • Earlier Start ‚Äì Preparations began weeks sooner, making readiness the default.
  • Broader Coverage ‚Äì More environments monitored; more signals tracked.
  • Smarter Insights ‚Äì AI models refined for sharper detection and faster recommendations.
  • Weekly Expert Reviews ‚Äì Turning meaningful signals into action before issues could escalate.

These SAP-driven enhancements meant less administrative effort, faster resolutions, and even greater confidence during the busiest shopping days of the year.

Behind the Scenes: How It Worked

  • Signal intelligence within SAP Commerce Cloud flagged performance, capacity, and configuration risks early.
  • AI-guided validations in SAP workflows turned insights into clear, actionable tasks.
  • Proactive SAP Support kicked in before thresholds became incidents.
  • Shared visibility aligned SAP operations and support for faster decisions.

Results at a Glance

  • Uninterrupted availability throughout the peak season
    Systems stayed online and stable during the busiest shopping days.
  • Faster analysis times ‚Äì improved by double digits
    Issue detection and resolution were significantly quicker compared to previous years.
  • Top-tier customer effort ratings for proactive support
    Customers rated the support experience highly because problems were prevented or resolved with minimal effort on their part.
  • Hundreds of potential issues resolved before impact
    Risks were identified and fixed early, avoiding disruptions for shoppers.
  • Major disruptions were prevented, ensuring smooth operations for nearly all customers
    Proactive measures kept severe-impact issues to near zero.

Who Benefited Most?

These benefits were felt across every SAP Commerce Cloud customer touchpoint ‚Äì from shoppers to business teams:

  • Shoppers Enjoyed Seamless Experiences
    Fast-loading pages, smooth checkout, and accurate inventory updates ‚Äì no frustrating delays.
  • Customers Felt Confident
    Reliable performance meant trust during big purchases, without fear of crashes or payment failures.
  • Support Was Faster and Quieter
    Issues were resolved behind the scenes before most customers even noticed.
  • Everyone Got What They Came For
    Deals stayed accessible, carts intact, and orders processed without hiccups ‚Äì maximizing satisfaction.

What‚Äôs Next

The journey doesn‚Äôt stop here. Businesses are extending this proactive approach year-round, scaling AI-driven detection, and broadening coverage to keep every season stress-free.

The goal? Continuous, intelligent readiness with SAP ‚Äì so you‚Äôre prepared well before the first order lands.

Keep your next peak season on track:

  • Talk to your SAP team about peak‚Äëseason preparedness for SAP Commerce Cloud
  • Join the SAP community conversation to share tips and get answers
  • Learn more about AI that‚Äôs woven into every SAP process

entry.title: SAP Developer News December 11th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

CAP November 2025 release

  • Release notes https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/releases/nov25
  • Blog post with release summary https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/what-s-new-in-sap-cloud-application-programming-model-november-2025/ba-p/14285849
  • Blog post on Status-Transition Flows https://qmacro.org/blog/posts/2025/12/08/a-simple-exploration-of-status-transition-flows-in-cap/

 

Micro-Integrations in AEM

  • Small but Great: Introducing Micro-Integrations for Advanced Event Mesh: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/small-but-great-introducing-micro-integrations-for-advanced-event-mesh/ba-p/14281037
  • Micro-Integrations documentation: https://help.pubsub.em.services.cloud.sap/Micro-Integrations/Managed/managed-micro-integrations-overview.htm

 

CAP Console

  • Blog Post: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/simplify-deployment-and-monitoring-with-the-cap-console/ba-p/14280836
  • Download: https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/#cloud-capconsole
  • Documentation: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/tools/console#the-cap-console

 

CAP Customer Roundtable 17 December

  • Agenda and meeting info https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-cloud-application-programming-model-cap-customer-roundtable-december/ba-p/14281737

 

Developing Transactional Apps with Collaborative Draft Capabilities

 

  • SAP Help Doc: https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-rap/adding-collaboration-capability-to-draft-enabled-managed-business-object?locale=en-US

RPT-1 is now GA

  • Free playground: https://rpt.cloud.sap/
  • Philipp Herzig‚Äôs blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/a-new-paradigm-for-enterprise-ai-in-context-learning-for-relational-data/ba-p/14260221

 

Devtoberfest Winner Interview - Leo van Hengel

Thank you to all Devtoberfest Speakers

==================================================================================================

 

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro

0:10 CAP November 2025 release

5:38 Micro-integrations in AEM

6:37 CAP Console

9:07 CAP Customer Roundtable 17 December

9:52 Developing Transactional Apps with Collaborative Draft Capabilities

11:03 RPT-1 is now GA

12:23 Devtoberfest Winner Interview - Leo van Hengel

13:18  Thank you to all Devtoberfest Speakers.

 

TRANSCRIPTION

 

Intro: This is the SAP Developer News for December 11th, 2025.

DJ:  The November 2025 release of CAP is out, bringing the Node.js runtime to 9.5, the Java runtime to 4.5, and the compiler to 6.5. This release brings lots of changes and additions. hybris just a brief overview. the status transition flows feature has graduated from being a lab preview to now being available as a beta feature and it's available in this release it's a beautiful example i think of CAP's what not how approach with even less code for us to write and maintain there's an important change in the CDS language and compiler area. Previously, annotations with indeterminate targets, typically due to typos, would cause a warning level message at compile time. This is okay, but for security-related annotations, an error level is better, and that's what we get now. moving to the node.js runtime there's new beta level support for Odata's dollar compute system query option an option which lets us specify arbitrary expressions think computed values driven from the client end via odata and in the java runtime there are various changes including some to which we need to pay attention. First, to enable consistent behavior across different databases, the runtime now handles numeric type promotion. This means, excuse me, that you might want to check that your handler code is not relying on specific types resulting from arithmetic expressions, which might now be different. In the context of draft-related entities, draft-enabled entities specifically, calculated elements are now evaluated properly when querying the underscore drafts table. If you've used virtual elements in the past, you might consider now moving to calculated elements so that you can reduce your custom code. There are also a number of improvements in the Java runtime to the outbox mechanism with an improved processing strategy, an optimized locking strategy, and also new observability possibilities as CAP's Java Outbox now publishes metrics to OpenTelemetry. Additionally, in the Java runtime, there's now support for CDS data in Spring REST controllers. There are enhancements to the cds .map-based elements. There's support for tree views on SQLite. You can also now use the shorthand protocol annotations like at OData rather than the long form. And in the area of reading media elements, a transaction is now always in force, but there's a way to turn this off in configuration. Now, moving from the runtimes to the plugin area, there have been some important fixes made to the attachment plugin and there are also some improvements now for example all hyperscaler object tools are supported there are improvements to malware scanning their support for localization and the visibility of attachment sections in the ui can now be controlled via annotations and these annotations of course can be dynamic with expressions moving on to the tools topic in CAP this november release brings a simplified a new simplified kima project setup and that's all via cds commands the cds CLI and that also sort of implies and means that the ctz package is now discontinued there's github action support now available for Java runtime projects and one of my favorite features of this release the command line formatter format cds now supports sources via standard in which makes it a lot easier to build in your own tools into your own personal development environment awesome and as you now know the monthly release notes also include a small set of highlights on what has been changed and updated in the documentation itself in capire and this time these updates include improved localized data documentation updates to the draft protection configuration details for the Java runtime an additional entry in the list of supported odata vocabularies that specifically is for the hierarchy vocabulary clarifications on draft aggregate draft aggregation support and various other improvements and enhancements far too many to list here well that wraps it up just about for this brief overview for the CAP November release check out all the details and more in the usual place in CAP higher link in the description

Antonio: Hola sap developers before i head out for a run i want to quickly share with you an exciting new feature that was just released in SAP Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh. The new feature is called Micro Integrations. In essence, a Micro Integration will allow you to easily connect your AEM broker with third-party services. The third-party service connector can be set as a source or target destination, meaning that you can quickly set up the flow of events from or to the third-party service. Some of the third-party services that are supported at the moment are Azure Service Bus, AWS SNS and SQS, IBM MQ, Google PubSub, and more microintegrations are planned to be made available. Check out Carson's blog post to learn more about microintegrations in SAP Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh.

Thomas: Hi, everybody. It's that time of year for holiday treats, and let's look under the tree here. I think we have something special, a little gift from the SAP Cloud Application Programming Team. Let's check out what it might be. What you see here is the all-new SAP Cap Console, a great little gift from the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Team that really helps developers, particularly those that are working with multiple projects locally in parallel. As you see here, it displays the different projects that I have on my local machine, makes it easy to open them in your designated editor. For instance, if I click this, it will open in Visual Studio Code. It also lets you easily open a project in the terminal or the file explorer or go to wherever the source control system is. In this case, you can see that the project is set up to go to GitHub. It also allows you to interact with a running application. For instance, I have this application running, and I can see deployment configuration. I can visit the user interface for a particular service, just bring up the testing interface. Here we are. Or I can visit the UI for an entire service, in which case it would bring up the CAP homepage for that service. from here i can continue testing with any of the particular entities and i can have the log come back out i say view log i can have log entries come back here instead of to the console so it gives me an easy place to test perhaps my favorite aspect though is the ad deployment that makes it easy to deploy your applications to BTP uh for instance i'll just log on here to BTP and once logged on i can choose the account that i want to deploy to and the sub account and then i can easily deploy to the cloud foundry runtime with an option to deploy to the kiba runtime coming soon so if you're a CAP developer then this is a tool you're going to want to be sure to install and have at your disposal

DJ: The last CAP customer round table of this year is next week Wednesday the 17th of December there's an agenda there's a meeting request that you can download and basically you know the drill if you've got insights requirements issues challenges topics that you want to discuss with your peers and also with the CAP team at SAP then the CAP customer roundtable is for you it's home to everybody so mark your diaries 17th of December 10 a.m. CET check out the link in the description for registering see you there

Shilpa: Hello ABAP developers, while working in RESTful Application Programming model, you might have already used draft functionality, which is so convenient to use because you can save the data in draft status. To add to this, a new feature, Collaborative Draft, is available, and with this, you can invite other users to work in the same transaction. Let me show how that works. In this transactional app, I want to create an entry, and you can see here there's a plus button which is enabled because collaborative draft is enabled for this now i want to invite sheena to give her input in this transaction and you can see here me and sheena can both work in the same transaction and we can also see each other's changes you can either save it or keep it as strat and the invited users also will get to know the status of the transaction to enable collaborative draft it needs to be defined in behavior definition a new action share has to be implemented. We need to have a draft query with the corresponding DCL so that the draft data can be controlled. Check out the help document and try out the collaborative draft functionality.

Nora: Thank you. Hi, I have some really cool news for those of you that got excited during the TechEd keynote when the RapidOne model was announced because it is now generally available in Generative AI Hub. So if you have an AI core instance with the extended plan, you can head right over and try out the models. Or if you do not, you can also check out the free playground on rpt.cloud.sap. And there you can also just try it out. So the way it works is that RapidOne is our foundation model. But unlike an LLM, it was not trained on a lot of language and can then predict the next word in a sequence or can answer your questions. But what it can do is, since it was trained on a lot of tabular data, it can fill in missing data points. And this is really cool because it is a pre-trained model. So you do not have to train anything yourself. The only thing that you have to do is provide a couple of lines from your data set that are actually complete so that the model can use those as context and basically as samples for any missing data points that you then want to be filled in. So you will provide the context, which is like a complete part of your table, just a couple of lines. It doesn't need a lot. And then a couple of lines where data points are missing and then the model will predict these missing data points based on the context so based on the lines that you gave it i think that's super cool i have a lot of fun trying it out myself make sure you head over and try it out yourself and let me know what you think so you joined it over first you did win the over one of the winners after

entry.title: Newly Redesigned Look - SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Applications
entry.content:
New changes are effective from Dec 11th 2025 on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry - Applications

SAP BTP CockpitÔºçRedesigned Application Overview Page

The Application Overview page now features a new design that makes it easier for you to manage and monitor your applications.

Here are the key changes:

  • The Application Details section shows the application name, lifecycle, buildpack, last updated timestamp, whether SSH is enabled or disabled, and the current stack.

  • You can map or unmap routes directly from the Mapped Routes section on the page. You no longer need to go to the Routes page for this task.

  • In the Instances Configuration section, you can scale your application by binding it to the Application Autoscaler service. Once it‚Äôs bound, you can access the Application Autoscaler dashboard from this section.

  • The Change Instance Details button is renamed to Change Configuration.

  • The Current Application Memory Usage and Available Space Memory are now easier to find.

  • The Start, Stop, and Restart buttons are moved to the upper right corner of the page.

  • The Add Instance and Remove Instance buttons are now part of the App Instances section.

  • In the App Instances section, the column titles have changed. State, Since, and CPU are renamed to Status, Running Since, and CPU Entitlement, respectively.

  • The Most Recent Application Events section is now called Recent Application Logs and Events. This section now includes the most recent application logs in addition to application events. It also allows you to access the dashboards of SAP Application Logging service or SAP Cloud Logging service, if your application is bound to these services.

  • You can no longer delete an application from this page because it was a rarely used option. To delete an application, go to the Applications page.

  • The auto refresh functionality on the Applications page is now disabled by default, allowing you to manually enable it if needed. This change helps prevent unintended rate limiting issues.

entry.title: Important Update: Tax Reporting Date Change for Canadian Company Codes
entry.content:
‚ú®At SAP, your feedback truly matters‚Äîand we take it seriously. Based on your input, we‚Äôve introduced an important change: the Tax Reporting Date will now always default to the Posting Date when creating accounting documents for Canadian company codes.

üìäThis means that SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) sales tax reports for Canada will now use the posting date as the tax reporting date.

üîçWhat‚Äôs Changing?

  • ‚úÖThe Tax Reporting Date is always suggested as the Posting Date for Canadian company codes, regardless of the T001-XSTDT configuration.
  • üõ†Standard Enhancement Implementation VATDATE_VALUES_DEFAULT_SAP from BAdI Definition VATDATE_RULES has been adjusted.

Depending on your SAP S/4HANA version:

  • üíªSAP S/4HANA & SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition:
    Please review SAP Note 3678561 ‚Äì DRC Canada: Corrections to Tax Reporting Date.
    Changes were made in the standard Enhancement Implementation VATDATE_VALUES_DEFAULT_SAP of BAdI VATDATE_VALUES. If you have a custom implementation of this BAdI, changes will not be reflected.

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èSAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:
    Starting December 14, 2025, your sales tax DRC reports will automatically use the posting date as the tax reporting date.

  • üÜïNew Customers:
    The updated logic will apply by default.

üìåExample:
If you receive and post a vendor invoice in January 2026 (posting date), but the document date is December 2025, DRC will include the invoice in the January 2026 tax report.

üìöWant to Learn More?
For more details about SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Canada, please visit the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) Automated iFlow Comparison and Summarization Using Generative AI
entry.content:
When multiple teams collaborate on the same SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) iFlow, changes can pile up quickly and it becomes difficult to pinpoint what was altered, who changed it, and which modifications must be transported to higher environments. To solve this, I built sapci_iflow_compare, a lightweight Streamlit app that fetches two iFlow XMLs and generates a technical, element-level diff, with an optional AI summary to make the results easy to review.

This blog walks through what the tool does and how to run it. It also explains why not to upload iFlow XMLs directly to public chatbots and how this approach keeps your content safer.

What the Solution Does

  • Connects to CI/CPI design‚Äëtime via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts to retrieve the selected iFlow‚Äôs ZIP and extract the .iflw XML for comparison (or accepts two local .iflw files) 
  • Matches nodes by id and performs a recursive comparison (attributes, text, structure), ignoring order differences where relevant, to produce a precise, developer‚Äëfriendly diff.
  • Displays the raw technical diff and (optionally) sends only the minimized difference report to Gemini for a human‚Äëreadable summary; you can disable the AI step entirely for strict confidentiality.

Architecture Overview

  • Inputs

Two CI/CPI design‚Äëtime endpoints (OAuth client credentials), or two local .iflw XMLs

 

  • API & Extraction

Calls /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts on your tenant to fetch the artifact content (ZIP) and extract the .iflw XML. 

 

  • Diff Engine

Parses both XMLs and generates an element‚Äëlevel diff with attribute and text changes. 

 

  • Optional AI Summary

Sends only the diff to Gemini for summarization, not the entire iFlow XML, keeping exposure to a minimum

Connectivity & Security: Fetching iFlow XMLs via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts

The tool connects to design‚Äëtime using the Integration Content OData API (OData V2), specifically the IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts resource exposed on SAP API Business Hub. This API supports downloading design‚Äëtime artifacts

Endpoint Pattern

  • Tenant base URL (design‚Äëtime):
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com
  • Resource path:
    /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Typical call:
    GET /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='<ArtifactId>',Version='<ArtifactVersion>')/$value
    (Exact resource and operations are documented in the API reference.) [api.sap.com]

Authentication

Use OAuth2 Client Credentials against your XSUAA token endpoint to obtain an access token, then call the API with that token. SAP‚Äôs help portal details roles and inbound HTTP client setup for Integration Content OData API access

Option A: Configure credentials in config_file.json

If your policy permits, store per‚Äëenvironment client credentials in the app‚Äôs JSON:

{
    "api1": {
      "name": "Source iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://source-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://source-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "source-client-id",
      "client_secret": "source-client-secret"
    },
    "api2": {
      "name": "Target iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://target-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://target-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "target-client-id",
      "client_secret": "target-client-secret"
    },
    "gemini_api_url": "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent",
    "gemini_api_key": "your-gemini-api-key"
  }
This uses the design‚Äëtime OData endpoint documented by SAP and the standard client‚Äëcredentials grant for server‚Äëto‚Äëserver integration.
 

Option B: Enter credentials at runtime in Streamlit

If storing secrets locally is a security concern, leave the client_id and client_secret blank in the config and enter them at runtime in the Streamlit UI. The app holds them in memory for the session and does not write them to disk. You‚Äôll input:

  • Tenant API URL:
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Token URL: https://<your-xsuaa-domain>/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: entered interactively in the UI

This approach adheres to the principle of minimizing persistence of credentials while leveraging the same SAP OData API

Setup & Run

  • Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare.git
cd sapci_iflow_compare
  • Install dependencies
pip3 install streamlit lxml requests
  • Choose your credential mode

Option A: Fill config_file.json with client credentials per environment.

Option B: Leave secrets empty and enter them at runtime via UI (recommended if local storage of secrets is not permitted).
(Both use the same SAP design‚Äëtime API.)

  • Run the app
python3 -m streamlit run iflow_compare.py
  • Click Compare iFlows to fetch, extract, and compare the two iFlow XMLs. Review the Raw Technical Diff and, if enabled, the AI Summary

Testing

  • I will use the Visual Studio code to run the .py file

  • Run the command

  • Page is opened in the browser as below and for simplicity, I will use Option A, using Config file, provide the config file path and click on compare iFlows

  • You can see the detailed differences of iFlow_1 and iFlow_2. If needed, it can be downloaded for detailed analysis

  • If needed, raw differences can be sent to Google Gemini and get the summary in readable format

This is just an idea and both difference logic and prompt can be extended as per the requirement

Recommended Use Cases

  1. Pre‚Äëtransport gate check
    Run a compare just before transport and attach the diff to your change ticket which mirrors best practice in community tools that emphasize confirming intended changes prior to moving artifacts. 

  2. Detect drift across packages/tenants
    Particularly useful when DEV and TEST coexist on the same tenant and packages fall out of sync is an issue documented by practitioners.

  3. Git workflows & automation
    Combine with GitHub sync (e.g., FlashPipe) and run the compare in a CI job or GitHub Action to block unintended changes on a pull request

Security: Why You Should Not Upload Full iFlow XMLs to Public Chatbots

Uploading raw iFlow XMLs (which may include endpoints, headers, and process logic) to public chatbots is risky:

  • Data training & retention: Public chatbot plans may use prompts to improve models and retain conversations (~30 days) even when training is disabled, which can violate internal policies for confidential data. (Enterprise plans have stronger guarantees, but that requires organizational adoption.) 

  • Real‚Äëworld incidents: Multiple organizations have restricted public chatbots after employees accidentally pasted confidential source code or internal materials; these cases underscore the leakage risk even when intentions are benign. 

  • SAP‚Äôs own caution: CI/CPI warns that placing sensitive values in headers or properties risks accidental exposure. Sending entire iFlow models externally increases that exposure surface. 

  • Safer pattern: Do your local comparison and, if you use AI, submit only a redacted difference report (no full iFlow XML) to your AI service or disable AI entirely. That is exactly how sapci_iflow_compare is designed

Conclusion

sapci_iflow_compare provides a repeatable, secure, and developer‚Äëfriendly way to compare iFlow changes across environments without exposing full iFlow XMLs to public chatbots. Whether you are preparing a transport, auditing changes, or reviewing a pull request, the element‚Äëlevel diff and optional readable summary help you move faster with confidence. As conveyed previously, this is an idea which can be extended as per your requirements.

  • GitHub: Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare

Please try it out, share feedback, and help improve the SAP integration ecosystem!

entry.title: Re: Requirement for Automatic Quotation Upload via Email
entry.content:
Good day @PRANAV-KUMAR 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, you cannot directly upload quotation from email into F1991 in public cloud. You can achieve that by:

  • Entering it manually,
  • integrating it from SAP Business Network/Ariba (Quote Automation/Sourcing), or
  • Using APIs to call your Supplier quotations from an external or BTP based solution.

Here is a link for some details: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/b6e67357efb1a86be10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

If you must start your process from email, you will need a custom BTP based email and document extraction flow that will create quotations through the standard APIs.

If you are open to portal-based collaboration, the recommended standard design is to integrate with SAP Business Network and let supplier submit quotes there, which will then flow automatically into manage supplier quotations.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - CDS Views Equivalent to On-Pre...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

There are multiple options on how you can find the CDS Views.

1.  via CDS Views Documentation

LINK -> https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/ee6ff9b281d8448f96b4fe6c89f2bdc8/5418de55938d1d22e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US

2. Visit the SAP Business Accelerator Hub and choose CDS Views from the Categories section. Within the Packages section of the CDS views screen, you can get a complete collection of CDS views tailored to various business areas within SAP S/4HANA.

LINK -> https://api.sap.com/content-type/CDSViews/onstackextensibility/cdsviews

3. Via Fiori View Browser app allows you to:

  • Search for released CDS Views available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • Identify data sources used by a CDS View (its underlying tables or other views).
  • See fields, associations, annotations, and usage.
  • Export a CDS View structure.

To get a list of all available CDS views, use the View Browser app.

One practical way to find the CDS View that replaces an on-premise table is by using the Fiori App: View Browser. (more information here https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/6b356c79dea443c4bbeeaf0865e04207/0bde695751505c08e10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US )

 

Below you can see how you can check the CDS views is in Fiori App View Browser.

1. Open the View Browser App

  1. Log into the Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Use the search bar to look for ‚ÄúView Browser.‚Äù
  3. Open the application.

 

2. Use the ‚ÄúAlternative Search‚Äù Function

At the top of the screen, instead of searching for a CDS view name, click Alternative Search. This feature allows you to search inside the metadata of CDS views ‚Äî including references to classical tables from the on-premise environment.

 

3. Configure the Search Options

In the popup window, choose the following settings:

  • Search In: Table & Column Names
  • Keyword: enter the on-premise table name you want to replace (Examples: KNB1, VBRK etc.)
  • Enable: Table Names
  • Click Search

 

4. Example: Searching for Table KNB1

When you search for KNB1, the system returns the CDS view: I_CustomerCompany

This tells you that:

  • I_CustomerCompany is mapped to the classical table KNB1
  • It belongs to the LO-MD-BP application component (Master Data ‚Äì Business Partner)
  • It is marked as Released, meaning it is safe to use and officially supported
  • It represents customer/company-code master data ‚Äî exactly what KNB1 stored in on-premise systems

 

5. Exploring the CDS View Details

Once you click on the CDS view (in this case, I_CustomerCompany), you can see several important sections that prove its relationship to the old table.

A. Definition Tab

This tab lists all the fields available in the CDS view, such as:

  • Customer (KUNNR)
  • CompanyCode (BUKRS)
  • ReconciliationAccount (AKONT)
  • AccountingClerk (BUSAB)

You will notice that these fields correspond directly to the fields stored in KNB1.

C. Cross Reference Tab

This tab shows all objects (tables, CDS Views, associations) related to the view. At the top, you will see: KNB1.

You also see additional Associations to other CDS views, such as:

  • I_Customer
  • I_CompanyCode
  • I_CustomerDunning
  • I_PaymentBlockingReason

Using the View Browser with Alternative Search allows you to identify which CDS Views replace classical on-premise tables.

 

Now let's check for the other tables. 

  • Table VBAP

 Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/abf7dc3d11d24976b77c1e78fe24b8a8.html?locale=en-US

 

 

  • Table VBRK

Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/116ddcc5a4f244a1a138c4a8146f8dc9.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBRP

IMPORTANT! Check link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/2485c474abf344b8b25756b29ac18c1a.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBAK

Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/955a323799624bd79221780675ada090.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBPA

IMPORTANT! Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/faa38d278eb3489693e02d5fcfb7ddd1.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBKD

VBKD in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Check below links for additional information:

 https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/new-data-architecture-in-sap-fi-on-s-4hana-cloud-what-every-functional/ba-p/14129021

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13545279

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13544498

 

  • Table BKPF

BKPF in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/bc3ccd578b90a856e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2602.VAL&q=journal%20entry

 

  • Table BSID

BSID in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Please check SAP NOTE https://me.sap.com/notes/0003596250

Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/ee6ff9b281d8448f96b4fe6c89f2bdc8/47dce95760521070e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2025.000&q=ACDOCA

Or link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/f585d657f8a28a3de10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2602.VAL

 

Check below links for additional information:

Link -  https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/new-data-architecture-in-sap-fi-on-s-4hana-cloud-what-every-functional/ba-p/14129021

Link - https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13545279

Link -  https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13544498

entry.title: Querying RDF Graphs with SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph Engine
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs multi-model platform brings together vector, graph, text, spatial, and relational data natively. It enables developers and data teams to build smarter, more context-aware AI solutions ‚Äî directly on operational data.

SAP HANA Cloud uniquely supports:

  • Vector data for semantic and similarity search
  • Graph data for explicit relationship modeling and knowledge graphs
  • Text and spatial data for real-world context
  • Relational data for structured operations and analytics

Rather than sending data across disparate services, you can store and process all of it in one place, accelerating time-to-value while reducing the risk of misalignment. This is multi-model done right, and it is the foundation for powerful AI workloads that scale.

This blog demonstrates how to query RDF knowledge graphs in SAP HANA Cloud, both:

  • Directly from the HANA Cloud Central SQL Console, and
  • Programmatically using Python

We will also show how RDF graphs can be combined seamlessly with vector similarity search, spatial filtering, and SQL analytics to create intelligent, real‚Äëworld use cases. The blog expands on this post.

From supplier notes to AI‚Äëready supply‚Äëchain intelligence

To ground the concepts, we start with a simple but realistic scenario: turning unstructured supplier feedback into AI‚Äëready supply‚Äëchain intelligence.

Step 1: Create a supply‚Äëchain schema and table

We first create a dedicated schema and table to store supplier identifiers, short operational reports, vector embeddings, and geographic locations.

CREATE SCHEMA KG_SUPPLYCHAIN;

CREATE TABLE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP (
  supplier_uri       NVARCHAR(200),
  report_text        NVARCHAR(1000),
  report_embedding   REAL_VECTOR(768),
  geo_location       ST_POINT(4326)
);

Step 2: Insert natural‚Äëlanguage supplier reports

The reports represent real‚Äëworld observations such as customs delays or smooth clearance. At this stage, AI embeddings and spatial attributes are not yet populated.

INSERT INTO KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP VALUES
('http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH', 'Consistently on time. No customs issue.', NULL, NULL),
('http://example.org/supplier/BetaGmbH',  'Severe customs delays reported last month.', NULL, NULL),
('http://example.org/supplier/GammaLogistics', 'Smooth operations, cleared customs quickly.', NULL, NULL);

Step 3: Add geographic context

Each supplier is enriched with a geographic location using WGS84 coordinates. This enables proximity analysis and regional risk assessment.

UPDATE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
SET geo_location = ST_GeomFromText('POINT(8.6821 50.1109)', 4326)
WHERE supplier_uri = 'http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH';

Step 4: Generate vector embeddings inside the database

SAP HANA Cloud generates vector embeddings directly in‚Äëdatabase using SAP‚Äôs native embedding model. This enables semantic understanding of supplier reports.

UPDATE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
SET report_embedding = VECTOR_EMBEDDING(
  report_text,
  'QUERY',
  'SAP_NEB.20240715'
);

At this point, we have a single AI‚Äëready table that supports:

  • Semantic similarity search
  • Spatial analysis
  • Generative AI grounding

‚Äîall without exporting data outside SAP HANA Cloud.

Adding semantic supplier knowledge with SAP HANA Knowledge Graph

Relational tables capture operational facts well, but business meaning and rules are better expressed semantically. This is where the SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph engine comes in.

Step 5: Initialize the RDF graph

We start by removing any existing graph to ensure a clean load.

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE('DROP GRAPH <kg_supplychain>', '', ?, ?);

Step 6: Insert semantic supplier knowledge

We then insert RDF triples describing suppliers and their business attributes. Each supplier uses the same URI as the relational table, creating a natural bridge between SQL and RDF.

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE(
'
INSERT DATA {
  GRAPH <kg_supplychain> {
    <http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH> a <Supplier> ;
      <hasCertification> "ISO 9001" ;
      <hasCarbonTaxRate> "low" ;
      <isFlaggedForDelays> false .
  }
}',
'', ?, ?);

Within the Knowledge Graph, suppliers are enriched with structured, machine‚Äëreadable facts such as certifications, carbon‚Äëtax exposure, and compliance flags.

The result is a dual‚Äëlayer architecture:

  • Relational layer: text, embeddings, spatial data
  • Semantic layer: business meaning, rules, and relationships

Both are connected by shared URIs and executed in the same database.

Querying across graph, vector, spatial, and SQL models

Query 1: Filter Knowledge Graph data directly in SQL

SAP HANA Cloud allows SPARQL queries to be consumed as relational tables using SPARQL_TABLE, enabling seamless integration with SQL analytics.

SELECT * FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
  SELECT ?supplier ?certification ?carbontax ?flag
  FROM <kg_supplychain>
  WHERE {
    ?supplier a <Supplier> .
    ?supplier <hasCertification> ?certification .
    ?supplier <hasCarbonTaxRate> ?carbontax .
    ?supplier <isFlaggedForDelays> ?flag .
    FILTER(
      ?certification = "ISO 9001" &&
      ?carbontax = "low" &&
      STR(?flag) = "false"
    )
  }
');

This bridges semantic reasoning and relational analytics in a single query flow.

Query 2: Hybrid SPARQL + SQL with vector and spatial filtering

This advanced query combines:

  1. Geospatial filtering (nearby suppliers)
  2. Vector similarity search on supplier reports
  3. Knowledge Graph constraints

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE(
'
SELECT *
FROM <kg_supplychain>
WHERE {
  SQL_TABLE("SELECT \"uri_str\", \"REPORT_TEXT\", \"SCO\" FROM (
    SELECT *, sco - FIRST_VALUE(sco) OVER(ORDER BY sco DESC) AS diff
    FROM (
      SELECT \"SUPPLIER_URI\" AS \"uri_str\", \"REPORT_TEXT\",
      COSINE_SIMILARITY(
        \"REPORT_EMBEDDING\",
        VECTOR_EMBEDDING(''no customs delay'', ''QUERY'', ''SAP_NEB.20240715'')
      ) AS sco
      FROM KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
      WHERE \"GEO_LOCATION\".ST_Distance(
        ST_GeomFromText(''POINT(8.6821 50.1109)'', 4326)
      ) < 50000
      ORDER BY sco DESC
    )
  ) WHERE diff > -0.2") .
}
ORDER BY DESC(?SCO)
LIMIT 10
',
'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv Content-Type: application/sparql-query',
?, ?);

This single query performs AI‚Äëdriven supplier discovery, ranking results by semantic meaning while respecting spatial and business rules.

Querying and managing Knowledge Graphs with Python

Beyond the SQL console, Knowledge Graphs can be managed programmatically using Python and the HANA DBAPI.

The following example shows how to:

  • Upload an RDF ontology (Turtle .ttl format)
  • Verify graph load success
  • Query RDF data programmatically
from hdbcli import dbapi

conn = dbapi.connect(
    address='XXX.hana.prod-ap10.hanacloud.ondemand.com',
    port=443,
    user='XXX',
    password='XXX'
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

Load an ontology into SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph

# Populate a new RDF in HANA Cloud with the turtle file content. We put the ontology into a specific graph.
ttl_filename = "/Users/materials_ontology.ttl"
graph_name = "materials_ontology"

# Load the ontology into HANA Cloud KG
print("Loading ontology...")

try:
    with open(ttl_filename, 'r') as ttlfp:
        request_hdrs = ''
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-protocol: true' + '\r\n'            # required header for upload protocol
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-filename: ' + ttl_filename + '\r\n' # optional header
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-graphname: ' + graph_name + '\r\n'   # optional header to specify name of the graph
        
        print(f"Loading file: {ttl_filename}")
        print(f"Graph name: {graph_name}")
        
        # Execute the load
        result = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (ttlfp.read(), request_hdrs, '?', None))
        print("Materials ontology loaded successfully!")
        print(f"Result: {result}")
        
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error loading materials ontology: {e}")
    print(f"Error type: {type(e)}")

Query the ontology 

Do note that you will have to adjust the query based on your ontology structure.

# Verify the materials ontology was loaded
print("Verifying materials ontology load...")

try:
    # Count triples in the materials graph
    query = f"""
    SELECT (COUNT(*) as ?Triples) 
    WHERE 
      {{ GRAPH <{graph_name}> 
          {{ ?s ?p ?o }} 
      }}
    """
    
    resp = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (query, 'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv', '?', None))
    print("Materials ontology statistics:")
    print(resp[2])
    
    # Query for some material instances
    query2 = f"""
    PREFIX mat: <http://example.com/materials/>
    PREFIX matprop: <http://example.com/materials/property/>
    
    SELECT ?material ?materialId ?level2 ?level3
    FROM <{graph_name}>
    WHERE {{
        ?material a mat:Material .
        ?material matprop:materialId ?materialId .
        OPTIONAL {{ ?material matprop:level2 ?level2 . }}
        OPTIONAL {{ ?material matprop:level3 ?level3 . }}
    }}
    LIMIT 5
    """
    
    resp2 = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (query2, 'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv', '?', None))
    print("\n Sample material instances:")
    print(resp2[2])
    
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error verifying materials ontology: {e}")

Summary

SAP HANA Cloud enables true multi‚Äëmodel intelligence by allowing relational data, vector embeddings, spatial context, and RDF knowledge graphs to coexist and execute together.

By combining in‚Äëdatabase vector embeddings, semantic Knowledge Graphs, and SQL, SPARQL, Python access, organizations can build powerful AI applications that are context‚Äëaware, explainable, and operationally grounded‚Äîall from a single platform.

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database for AI. It is where data, meaning, and intelligence converge.

entry.title: Master Cloud Customer Agreement Enrollment (MCCA) in SAP for Me!
entry.content:
SAP now offers a convenient self-service feature for corporate customers: request your Master Cloud Customer Agreement (MCCA) directly through SAP for Me. This streamlined process separates MCCA signing from commercial negotiations, allowing you to review and sign the agreement at your convenience.

With the intuitive MCCA card available in the Finance & Legal Dashboard, you are guided through a simple three-step process: review a legal disclaimer, enter your signatory details, and select your preferred language. Once submitted, the MCCA document will be delivered via DocuSign‚Äôs secure website for review and signature.

Take advantage of this new capability to accelerate your cloud contracting journey and ensure a smoother, more flexible experience with SAP.

What is the Master Cloud Customer Agreement?  

The Master Cloud Customer Agreement (MCCA) is SAP‚Äôs standard Terms & Conditions that apply across most of SAP's Cloud portfolio available as a simple Frame Agreement enrollment, making it easier for customers to engage with SAP‚Äôs cloud offerings. For more information on the enrollment procedure and full details on MCCA, please refer to this Knowledgebase Article.
